trans-unit.source: Using offline data in your universal Windows app | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using offline data in your universal Windows app | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services to cache and sync offline data in your universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add offline support to a Windows Universal Store app using Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add offline support to a Windows Universal Store app using Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Offline support will allow you to interact with a local database when your app is in an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: Offline support will allow you to interact with a local database when your app is in an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: Once your app is online with the backend database, you sync your local changes using the offline features.
trans-unit.target: Once your app is online with the backend database, you sync your local changes using the offline features.

trans-unit.source: If you prefer to watch a video, the clip to the right follows the same steps as this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you prefer to watch a video, the clip to the right follows the same steps as this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you update the Universal app project from the [Get started with Mobile Services] tutorial to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you update the Universal app project from the [Get started with Mobile Services] tutorial to support the offline features of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: Then you will add data in a disconnected offline scenario, sync those items to the online database, and then log in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.
trans-unit.target: Then you will add data in a disconnected offline scenario, sync those items to the online database, and then log in to the Azure Management Portal to view changes to data made when running the app.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is intended to help you better understand how Mobile Services enables you to use Azure to store and retrieve data in a Windows Store app.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is intended to help you better understand how Mobile Services enables you to use Azure to store and retrieve data in a Windows Store app.

trans-unit.source: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, you should complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] first.
trans-unit.target: If this is your first experience with Mobile Services, you should complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] first.

trans-unit.source: The older Windows Phone 8 tutorial for Visual Studio 2012 is still available here, [Windows Phone 8 Tutorial for Visual Studio 2012].
trans-unit.target: The older Windows Phone 8 tutorial for Visual Studio 2012 is still available here, [Windows Phone 8 Tutorial for Visual Studio 2012].

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.

trans-unit.source: Completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services].
trans-unit.target: Completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services].

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SDK version 1.3.0 (or later)[mobile services sdk nuget]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SDK version 1.3.0 (or later)[mobile services sdk nuget]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 1.0.0 (or later)[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Mobile Services SQLite Store version 1.0.0 (or later)[sqlite store nuget]</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>SQLite for Windows 8.1</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>SQLite for Windows 8.1</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: An Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile services that you can keep using even after your trial ends.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can sign up for an Azure trial and get up to 10 free mobile services that you can keep using even after your trial ends.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <linkText>Azure Free Trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.
trans-unit.target: Azure Mobile Services offline features allow you to interact with a local database when you are in an offline scenario with your Mobile Service.

trans-unit.source: To use these features in your app, you initialize a MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.
trans-unit.target: To use these features in your app, you initialize a MobileServiceClient.SyncContext to a local store.

trans-unit.source: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.
trans-unit.target: Then reference your table through the IMobileServiceSyncTable interface.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial we use SQLite for the local store.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial we use SQLite for the local store.

trans-unit.source: You can skip this section and just get the example project that already has offline support from the GitHub samples repository for Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: You can skip this section and just get the example project that already has offline support from the GitHub samples repository for Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: The sample project with offline support enabled is located here, [TodoList Offline Sample].
trans-unit.target: The sample project with offline support enabled is located here, [TodoList Offline Sample].

trans-unit.source: Install the SQLite runtime for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.
trans-unit.target: Install the SQLite runtime for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1.

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Runtime: Install [SQLite for Windows 8.1].
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Runtime: Install [SQLite for Windows 8.1].

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 8.1: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8.1].
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 8.1: Install [SQLite for Windows Phone 8.1].

trans-unit.source: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.
trans-unit.target: If you are using Internet Explorer, clicking the link to install SQLite may prompt you to download the .vsix as a .zip file.

trans-unit.source: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.
trans-unit.target: Save the file to a location on your hard drive with the .vsix extension instead of .zip.

trans-unit.source: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.
trans-unit.target: The double click the .vsix file in Windows Explorer to run the installation.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Get started with Mobile Services] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio open the project that you completed in the [Get started with Mobile Services] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore NuGet package for the Windows 8.1 runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.
trans-unit.target: Install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore NuGet package for the Windows 8.1 runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 projects.

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1: In Solution Explorer, right click the Windows 8.1 project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1: In Solution Explorer, right click the Windows 8.1 project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.
trans-unit.target: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 8.1: Right click the Windows Phone 8.1 project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 8.1: Right click the Windows Phone 8.1 project and click Manage Nuget Packages to run NuGet Package Manager.

trans-unit.source: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.
trans-unit.target: Search for SQLiteStore to install the WindowsAzure.MobileServices.SQLiteStore package.

trans-unit.source: If the installation creates a reference to an older version of SQLite, you can just delete that duplicate reference.
trans-unit.target: If the installation creates a reference to an older version of SQLite, you can just delete that duplicate reference.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click References for the Windows 8.1 Runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 platform projects and ensure there is a reference to SQLite, which is located in the Extensions section.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click References for the Windows 8.1 Runtime and Windows Phone 8.1 platform projects and ensure there is a reference to SQLite, which is located in the Extensions section.

trans-unit.source: <linkText></linkText> </br>
trans-unit.target: <linkText></linkText> </br>

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Runtime
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Runtime

trans-unit.source: <linkText></linkText> </br>
trans-unit.target: <linkText></linkText> </br>

trans-unit.source: Windows Phone 8.1
trans-unit.target: Windows Phone 8.1

trans-unit.source: The SQLite Runtime requires you to change the processor architecture of the project being built to x86, x64, or ARM.
trans-unit.target: The SQLite Runtime requires you to change the processor architecture of the project being built to x86, x64, or ARM.

trans-unit.source: Any CPU is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Any CPU is not supported.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, click the Solution at the top, then change the processor architecture drop down box to one of the supported settings that you want to test.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, click the Solution at the top, then change the processor architecture drop down box to one of the supported settings that you want to test.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, in the shared project, open the MainPage.cs file.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, in the shared project, open the MainPage.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment the following using statements at the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Uncomment the following using statements at the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.cs, comment the definition of todoTable and uncomment the one on the following line that calls MobileServicesClient.GetSyncTable():
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.cs, comment the definition of todoTable and uncomment the one on the following line that calls MobileServicesClient.GetSyncTable():

trans-unit.source: In MainPage.cs, in the region marked Offline sync, uncomment the methods InitLocalStoreAsync and SyncAsync.
trans-unit.target: In MainPage.cs, in the region marked Offline sync, uncomment the methods InitLocalStoreAsync and SyncAsync.

trans-unit.source: The method InitLocalStoreAsync initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.
trans-unit.target: The method InitLocalStoreAsync initializes the client sync context with a SQLite store.

trans-unit.source: In the OnNavigatedTo event handler, uncomment the call to InitLocalStoreAsync:
trans-unit.target: In the OnNavigatedTo event handler, uncomment the call to InitLocalStoreAsync:

trans-unit.source: Uncommment the 3 calls to SyncAsync in the methods InsertTodoItem, UpdateCheckedTodoItem, and ButtonRefresh_Click:
trans-unit.target: Uncommment the 3 calls to SyncAsync in the methods InsertTodoItem, UpdateCheckedTodoItem, and ButtonRefresh_Click:

trans-unit.source: Add exception handlers in the SyncAsync method:
trans-unit.target: Add exception handlers in the SyncAsync method:

trans-unit.source: In this example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we retrieve all records in the remote todoTable, but it is also possible to filter records by passing a query.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter to PullAsync is a query ID that is used for incremental sync, which uses the UpdatedAt timestamp to get only records modified since the last sync.

trans-unit.source: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.
trans-unit.target: The query ID should be a descriptive string that is unique for each logical query in your app.

trans-unit.source: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.
trans-unit.target: To opt-out of incremental sync, pass null as the query ID.

trans-unit.source: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.
trans-unit.target: This will retrieve all records on each pull operation, which is potentially inefficient.

trans-unit.source: * To remove records from the device local store when they have been deleted in your mobile service database, you should enable [Soft Delete].
trans-unit.target: * To remove records from the device local store when they have been deleted in your mobile service database, you should enable [Soft Delete].

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, your app should periodically call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, your app should periodically call IMobileServiceSyncTable.PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.

trans-unit.source: Note that the MobileServicePushFailedException can occur for both a push and a pull operation.
trans-unit.target: Note that the MobileServicePushFailedException can occur for both a push and a pull operation.

trans-unit.source: It can occur for a pull because the pull operation internally executes a push to make sure all tables along with any relationships are consistent.
trans-unit.target: It can occur for a pull because the pull operation internally executes a push to make sure all tables along with any relationships are consistent.

trans-unit.source: The next tutorial, [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services], shows how to handle these sync related exceptions.
trans-unit.target: The next tutorial, [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services], shows how to handle these sync related exceptions.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.

trans-unit.source: The app will behave the same as it did before the offline sync changes, because it does a sync operation on the insert, update, and refresh operations.
trans-unit.target: The app will behave the same as it did before the offline sync changes, because it does a sync operation on the insert, update, and refresh operations.

trans-unit.source: In this section, you will modify the app so that it does not sync on the insert and update operations, but only when the Refresh button is pressed.
trans-unit.target: In this section, you will modify the app so that it does not sync on the insert and update operations, but only when the Refresh button is pressed.

trans-unit.source: Then, you will break the app connection with the mobile service to simulate an offline scenario.
trans-unit.target: Then, you will break the app connection with the mobile service to simulate an offline scenario.

trans-unit.source: When you add data items, they will be held in the local store, but not synced to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When you add data items, they will be held in the local store, but not synced to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Open MainPage.cs in the shared project.
trans-unit.target: Open MainPage.cs in the shared project.

trans-unit.source: Edit the methods InsertTodoItem and UpdateCheckedTodoItem to comment out the calls to SyncAsync.
trans-unit.target: Edit the methods InsertTodoItem and UpdateCheckedTodoItem to comment out the calls to SyncAsync.

trans-unit.source: Edit App.xaml.cs in the shared project.
trans-unit.target: Edit App.xaml.cs in the shared project.

trans-unit.source: Comment out the initialization of the MobileServiceClient and add the following lines, which use an invalid mobile service URL:
trans-unit.target: Comment out the initialization of the MobileServiceClient and add the following lines, which use an invalid mobile service URL:

trans-unit.source: In InitLocalStoreAsync(), comment out the call to SyncAsync(), so that the app does not perform a sync on launch.
trans-unit.target: In InitLocalStoreAsync(), comment out the call to SyncAsync(), so that the app does not perform a sync on launch.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to build and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to build and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Enter some new todo items and click Save for each one.
trans-unit.target: Enter some new todo items and click Save for each one.

trans-unit.source: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The new todo items exist only in the local store until they can be pushed to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The client app behaves as if its connected to the mobile service supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations.
trans-unit.target: The client app behaves as if its connected to the mobile service supporting all create, read, update, delete (CRUD) operations.

trans-unit.source: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.
trans-unit.target: Close the app and restart it to verify that the new items you created are persisted to the local store.

trans-unit.source: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In this section you reconnect the app to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This simulates the app moving from an offline state to an online state with the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: When you press the Refresh button, data will be synced to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When you press the Refresh button, data will be synced to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Open App.xaml.cs in the shared project.
trans-unit.target: Open App.xaml.cs in the shared project.

trans-unit.source: Uncomment your previous initialization of MobileServiceClient to add back the correct mobile service URL and app key.
trans-unit.target: Uncomment your previous initialization of MobileServiceClient to add back the correct mobile service URL and app key.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the data looks the same as the offline scenario even though the app is now connected to the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the data looks the same as the offline scenario even though the app is now connected to the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This is because this app always works with the IMobileServiceSyncTable that is pointed to the local store.
trans-unit.target: This is because this app always works with the IMobileServiceSyncTable that is pointed to the local store.

trans-unit.source: Log into the Microsoft Azure Management portal and look at the database for your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Microsoft Azure Management portal and look at the database for your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If your service uses the JavaScript backend for mobile services, you can browse the data from the Data tab of the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: If your service uses the JavaScript backend for mobile services, you can browse the data from the Data tab of the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, in Visual Studio go to Server Explorer -> Azure -> SQL Databases.
trans-unit.target: If you are using the .NET backend for your mobile service, in Visual Studio go to Server Explorer -> Azure -> SQL Databases.

trans-unit.source: Right click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Right click your database and select Open in SQL Server Object Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Notice the data has not been synchronized between the database and the local store.
trans-unit.target: Notice the data has not been synchronized between the database and the local store.

trans-unit.source: In the app, press the Refresh button.
trans-unit.target: In the app, press the Refresh button.

trans-unit.source: This causes the app to call PushAsync and PullAsync.
trans-unit.target: This causes the app to call PushAsync and PullAsync.

trans-unit.source: This push operation sends the local store items to the mobile service, then retrieves new data from the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This push operation sends the local store items to the mobile service, then retrieves new data from the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: A push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable and pushes changes on all tables associated with that sync context.
trans-unit.target: A push operation is executed off the MobileServiceClient.SyncContext instead of the IMobileServicesSyncTable and pushes changes on all tables associated with that sync context.

trans-unit.source: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.
trans-unit.target: This is to cover scenarios where there are relationships between tables.

trans-unit.source: In the app, click the check box beside a few items to complete them in the local store.
trans-unit.target: In the app, click the check box beside a few items to complete them in the local store.

trans-unit.source: Push the Refresh button again, which causes SyncAsync to be called.
trans-unit.target: Push the Refresh button again, which causes SyncAsync to be called.

trans-unit.source: SyncAsync calls both push and pull, but in this case we could have removed the call to PushAsync.
trans-unit.target: SyncAsync calls both push and pull, but in this case we could have removed the call to PushAsync.

trans-unit.source: This is because a pull always does a push first.
trans-unit.target: This is because a pull always does a push first.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure all tables in the local store along with relationships remain consistent.

trans-unit.source: [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services]
trans-unit.target: [Handling conflicts with offline support for Mobile Services]
